MAIN ESTIMATES AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES FOR 1962


    Committee of Supply
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: In accordance with the provisions of paragraph (6) of Standing Order No. 86 and paragraph (5) of Standing Order No. 87, I have for both the Main Estimates and the Development Estimates for 1962 fixed the times on each allotted day at which consideration of the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper shall, if not previously disposed of, be concluded. Those times will be circulated to Honourable Members and will appear in the Official Report*. I might add that the amount of time requested by Honourable Members exceeds the time available by almost four times, and it has accordingly become necessary to cut the time requested drastically, sometimes by more than three-quarters. It would therefore be necessary for Honourable Members who have given notice of amendments to endeavour to get together to share the time which has been made available for each head of expenditure. It is appreciated, of course, that Budget time or Supply time is Opposition time and they must make the best use of the time available.

SUSPENSION OF STANDING
ORDER


2.38 p.m.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, I beg to move,

    That, notwithstanding the Standing Orders, the Fifth Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure of the State of Singapore for 1961 (contained in Paper Cmd. 37 of 1961) and the resumed debate on the motion of the Minister for Finance relating to the financial policy of the year 1962 be taken today.

    Question proposed.

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Speaker, Sir, in the light of the possibility that the Leader of the House is not acquainted with the constitutional traditions of procedure, I would like to remind him that Budget Day - as this day is, as, in fact, you have just informed the House - is a day for the Opposition. There are five hours, Sir, between 2.30 and 8 p.m., our normal time, when the Budget debate takes place. The Opposition has met and the

Column: 1532

leaders have allocated amongst themselves the time which is theirs which is 4½ hours, leaving half an hour to Government, which is the traditional procedure in this matters. If the Leader of the House is of the view that the debate on the Fifth Supplementary Estimates would take so long as to eat into that half-hour, then the Opposition can meet and surrender part of its 4½ hours. But if the intention is that the. Government Front Benches or the Government side should have more than the traditional time to which it is entitled, Sir, I will oppose this motion, not because today having received notice I am not prepared to sit till late, but because I am not prepared to contravene the spirit of the democratic traditions of parliamentary procedure.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, the Member for Anson has said it is the practice for Government benches to be allowed only half an hour. This is the first time I have heard of this practice. Could he please elaborate? It is not my recollection that that was the practice we had last year and the previous year.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sure the Front Bench will accept it from me. Could I crave the Chair's indulgence? The Chair is acquainted with traditions, and I am sure the whole House will receive an indication from you, Sir, as to what the proper procedure is.

    Mr Speaker: I think I have indicated in the past that in all these matters, the parliamentary practice in other Parliaments is for agreement to be arrived at between the Government side and the Opposition side through the usual channels. That means that the Government Whip and the Opposition Whip - if there is an Opposition Whip - get together, decide as to what time should be made available to each other when there is limited time available, decide on the number of speakers and so on and so forth, so that the business on which there is a guillotine could be completed satisfactorily to both sides.

    As far as our Standing Orders are concerned, the position is that, ordinarily, the resumed debate on the

Column: 1533

Question, "That the Assembly approves the financial policy of the Government for the year 1962", should take from 3 p.m. (not 2.30 p.m.) to 8 p.m. Ordinarily also, if there is other business of Supply, that business of supply should be taken on a separate allotted day. But there have been cases where it is anticipated that one business of Supply would not take unduly long, and it has been the practice in the past for the type of motion which has been moved by the Leader of the House to be moved and accepted by the House. I think the Leader of the House will remember that there is an implicit understanding that if the first business of Supply enroaches on the time of the second business of supply, then he will undertake to move, at the end of the day, the suspension of Standing Orders, so that the time taken up by the first business of Supply could be added on to the time taken up by the second business of Supply after 8 p.m. That is roughly the position.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Sir, it is not my intention to rob Members of the Opposition of any time they wish to use to speak during the course of this debate, but as you have pointed out, according to page 6 of the Standing Orders, there is a footnote down there, which says quite correctly:

    'The resumed Debate on the Annual Budget Statement or Business of Supply is taken at 3 p.m. on an allotted day....'

    We are now approximately at 2.44 p.m. If by 3 p.m. we do not finish the debate on the Fifth Supplementary Estimates, then at 3 p.m. we will automatically go on to the resumed debate on the Budget Statement. We will continue with the Fifth Supplementary Estimates, and at the moment of interruption we will extend whatever time that is lost.

    Mr Speaker: I do not think I have answered the Minister for Finance. He wants to know whether there is a constitutional practice where the Minister is allowed half an hour for a reply -

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The whole of it.

    Mr Speaker: Well, the Ministerial bench. The answer is no. There is no

Column: 1534

such constitutional practice. All these things are made by arrangement. It might well be that the Opposition might think that even the time allotted by the Standing Orders is such that it is not sufficient for them to complete what they want to say and, therefore, insufficient for them to give any time to The Ministerial bench to answer any points they have made. That is left entirely to the Opposition. If they want an answer to the points they have made, then, of course, they should, of their own volition, allow certain time for Ministers of the Government bench to answer the points made.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Resolved,

    That, notwithstanding the Standing Orders, the Fifth Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure of the State of Singapore for 1961 (contained in Paper Cmd. 37 of 1961) and the resumed debate on the motion of the Minister for Finance relating to the financial policy of the year 1962 be taken today.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, do I now understand that Standing Orders are suspended merely for the time that may be required between 3 p.m. and such time as we start the Budget debate - only that extra time?

    Mr Speaker: Actually the Standing Orders have not yet been suspended insofar as that aspect of the case is concerned. The Standing Orders will be suspended between 7 p.m. and 7.30 p.m. The Leader of the House has given an undertaking that he will add to the time available for the Budget debate the time which is to be or may be taken up by consideration of the Fifth Supplementary Estimates.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I so signify.

    The Chairman: We are now on the Fifth Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1961 contained in Paper Cmd. 37 of 1961. The summary is at page 1.

    There is an amendment to Head 28 - Ministry of Finance standing in the name of the Member for Tanglin in relation to subhead 53. Dr Thio Chan Bee.

    Dr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 28 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 53.

    Sir, it is not usual for Government to include an item involving such a huge sum as $80 million in the Supplementary Estimates. Naturally, Sir, when I saw this item, I wondered why the Minister for Finance had done so. When I read the explanation, I found it to be so meagre that I was left totally in the dark.

    Mr David Marshall: Hear, hear!

    Dr Thio Chan Bee: Then again with the Budget Estimates for 1962 coming up, one naturally wondered why this item could not have been included in those Estimates. Therefore, we want the Minister for Finance to clarify the position and justify his request for such a big sum. We would like to know, Sir, why it is so urgent that such a big sum must be included in the Supplementary Estimates. What are the schemes which are so urgent for the money to be provided rightaway? We would suggest that, in future, when requests are made for such big sums, fuller explanations be given to the House.

    We would also like to know from which unspent balance this sum is going to be transferred.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I must accept responsibility for the somewhat meagre explanation. I think there is a point in the criticism made by the Member for Tanglin. I must say I regret that a fuller explanation for asking this large amount was not given in the Command Paper.

Column: 1536



    I must say, however, that it is not true that this thing is not usual. I am speaking from memory, but I think it was in the year 1954 or 1956 thereabouts when similar transfers of sums were made from the revenue balance to the Development Fund. Perhaps I should explain here to Members who may not be familiar with financial procedure that we keep Government monies in two large funds. One is the Consolidated Fund into which all revenues are paid and against which all current expenditure is charged. The other one is the Development Fund which goes towards paying for projects in the Four-Year Development Plan approved by the Assembly. The disbursement of money in the Development Fund is controlled by the Assembly itself, either year by year, or by Supplementary Estimates as the need arises.

    Sir, briefly, the position is this. When we draw up the Four-Year Development Plan, we not only set out the major development projects which the State hoped to undertake in the course of the next four years, but we also made a calculation of the resources that were available then for meeting this rather large sum of capital expenditure. Copies of this blue book were circulated to all Members in the House, and I have no doubt that the Member for Tanglin has diligently perused the contents of this book. However, I would like to refresh his memory on this point. In Chapter V of the Plan entitled "Financing the Plan", we described various sources of finance such as surpluses from current revenue, the present financial resources of the Government, City Council Public Utilities, loans (World Bank loans and loans raised locally), and so forth. On page 47, you will see a recapitulation of resources available at that time. They included a transfer from the Consolidated Revenue Account, which is the Consolidated Fund, of $57.2 million, a transfer of $20 million from the Contingency Fund/Advance Accounts, a sum of $9.4 million from unexpended loan proceeds; and on another page we stated that local loans would have to be raised of which about $50 million is expected to be raised in the form of

Column: 1537

Treasury bills. So these are the sums roughly calculated in drawing up the Plan. These are the sums which represent the financial resources initially available.

    Sir, if you add the $57.2 million to be transferred from the Consolidated Fund, the $20 million representing a running down of the Advance Accounts, and the $9.4 million representing the unexpended loan proceeds, you will get a total of, I make it, $87 million. Then, of course, we wanted to keep a part of the loans to be raised on Treasury hills in long-term securities in the Development Fund. So in fact, the operation to be carried out according to the Development Plan will be a sum much higher than $80 million. One of the reasons is that the value of Treasury bills floated in the market has not been as much as we had hoped. So I limited this transfer from the Consolidated Fund to the Development Fund to $80 million. Of course, this is rather necessary because the Development Fund itself is running down in spite of the fact that we floated a loan of $50 million this year. By the end of this year, we have our payments for development expenditure out of this Development Fund. We may get a total of some $51 million as against $87 million which we started with at the beginning of this year. So with the transfer of some $80 million to the Development Fund, we will then get a fairly respectable figure of $171 million roughly for the Development Fund for use next year. We will be making transfers from the Consolidated Fund to the Development Fund as and when the need arises.

    I hope my explanation is clear to the Member for Tanglin. I think I do owe to Members of the House an apology for not setting it out in the Command Paper.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I refer the Minister for Finance to page 49 of his Development Plan. Paragraph 5.26 sets out the heads under which he proposes to finance tile Plan. $871 million was the total required to finance the Plan of

Column: 1538

which he hoped to get $116.1 million from Revenue Surplus. Now if I understand Revenue Surplus correctly, it means money saved from revenue. For the year 1961, there was a vote of $30 million as contribution from revenue to the Development Fund. In the 1962 Estimates, there is a further sum of $30 million by way of contribution to the Development Fund. $30 million plus $30 million makes $60 million. Now $80 million from current revenue makes it $140 million. Do I understand the Minister to say that revenue has exceeded his most sanguine hopes when he hoped to finance the $871 million to the point of $116 million from revenue'?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, that is not the position. When we said surplus here, we meant really surplus after the $30 million had been deducted in the normal course of events in the ordinary Estimates, so that to realise the Plan, you would have to have a series of Budget surpluses not only in Development, but also in Public Utilities, Harbour Board, and so on. Have I made my point clear?

    Mr Rajah: As I understand it from the Minister for Finance, of the $116.1 million which he hoped to get from Revenue Surplus, the $80 million which he is now asking the House would go towards part of that $116.1 million. He is now asking the House to vote another $80 million to the Development Fund. I take it it is from Revenue Surplus.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Perhaps he has got the book there. May I refer him to page 47, paragraph 5.17?

There is also a transfer of $20 million of the Contingency Fund into the Advance Account, because, in reviewing the various accounts, we found there was an over-provision and we could safely reduce that amount

by $20 million. Then there is the "Unexpended loan proceeds" which is still in the General Revenue Balance.

    So this roughly makes up the sum of $80 million. And, of course, we have floated Treasury bills, as we have said, part of which proceeds we want to put in the development fund.

    Mr Rajah: Do I understand the Hon, the Minister for Finance to say this: that this $80 million then is the sum set out under "Consolidated Revenue Account $57.2 million" and the sum set out against "Contingency Fund/Advance Accounts $20 million", making $77.2 million. That is the amount he is now asking to be transferred to the Development Fund, and that this $80 million is not from any surplus revenue for the year 1961. Is that correct?

    Dr Thio Chan Bee: Mr Speaker, Sir, just for further clarification. In the Budget Estimates, page 8, I see the following particulars, "Deduct Deficit for 1961". Just one question, Sir. If there was not this item of $80 million to be transferred to the Development Fund, would that have altered the statement there, so that instead of a deficit, there would have been a surplus?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: My recollection is this: it took some time before we transferred this. My recollection is that this is based on the Estimates presented to the Assembly last year plus the changes allowed for increasing costs, variable allowances, and so on.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [28th November, 1961], "That the Assembly approves the financial policy of the Government for the year 1962."

    Question again proposed.

Column: 1541



    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance has found it fit to refer to the Barisan Sosialis in his speech on the financial policy of the Government for the year 1962.

    Mr Rajah: You should have been honoured!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: He has suggested that we should not be unmindful of the hard economic facts facing the people of Singapore. Sir, we are not only conversant with the stern economic realities confronting us, but we are also acutely conscious of the need to put up with them and to make the best possible job of it. We are well aware of the entrepot nature of Singapore's economy. We are aware of Singapore's growing population. We are aware and are keenly desirable of industrial peace, because this is closely tied up with the need for industrialisation upon which so much of our population would depend for jobs in the near future. Sir, it is because of our consciousness of the delicate nature of our economy and the magnitude of our problem we have to face that we feel the co-operation of the entire people is a prerequisite for the success of any government.

    Sir, it is here that I have to remind the P.A.P. Government where they have blundered, namely, that in their budgeting, in their taxation policy, in their efforts to work out a policy of collection of revenue, and in their order of priorities in respect of expenditure of public needs, they do not seem to have taken into account the feelings and desires of the people. Sir, it is here that we have to teach the P.A.P. Government a simple but nevertheless grim fact amongst all other objective economic realities. That is, that we have a politically conscious people and an educated populace who could be persuaded to accept policies, and even hardships that may follow from these policies, if they are satisfied that Government is in sympathy with their basic problems and aspirations. Sir, the necessity of the people's co-operation is fundamental, especially when the people of Singapore are politically

Column: 1542

volatile. I would ask the Minister for Finance to remember this reality. It is a particularly pertinent reminder, for he and most of his ministerial colleagues have been extremely ham-fisted in the application of their policies.

    Mr David Marshall: Hear, hear!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I must remind the Minister for Finance that he cannot treat people like pawns on the chessboard, and that policies which hurt the people or even appear to do so are ultimately going to be rejected by the people.

    Sir, the speech of the Minister has given no great comfort to the people of Singapore. He justifies his proposed Budget by the assertion that expenditure on various items has been greater than that of preceding years. Sir, this is a rather naive way of trying to get acceptance of Government's financial policy. Our revenues have increased, and so expenditure of our various social services has also increased together with the expenditure on various other items. There is nothing new or startling in this simple fact. There is no reason for the Minister for Finance to make a special point of it.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I would.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, let me examine certain main features of the Minister's speech. The Minister says that the development expenditure for the year 1961 would amount to $100-$110 million and, according to the Minister, this is an all-time record in Singapore. Sir, is this really true? I do not think he dares even answer that.

    In page 8 of the Development Estimates for 1962, the grand total for 1961 quoted for development was $166.2 million. Of this, how much is really going to be spent by the end of the year? The estimated expenditure is to be $107.8 million. Therefore, the Government is going to spend only 65 per cent of what has been allocated for development. But, unfortunately, even this amount would not be spent. Of the $107.8 million. $40 million is, in fact, a paper transfer. So actually the amount to be spent by the end of 1962,

Column: 1543

if indeed that amount will be spent, will be $107.8 million minus $40 million, that is $67.8 million. If you are to work it out, this is only 41 per cent performance.

    Sir, it is interesting to note that this $67.8 million is much lower than the pre-P.A.P. years. It is much lower than what the Lim Yew Hock Government had spent. If you turn to page 25 of the Development Plan, Sir, in Table 2.11, under the title "Capital Expenditure 1955-1960", you will see under column 1955, (at the bottom of it); $89.2 million; 1956, $83.9 million; 1957, $118.4 million; 1958, the figure is also $118.4 million. But when it comes to 1959 and 1960, there are only $73.5 million for 1959 and $66.6 million for 1960.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: On a point of elucidation, Sir.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh resumed his seat.

    Mr Speaker: Dr Gob, point of elucidation, if it is not too lengthy.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Yes, Sir. I would ask the Member whether he is aware that the total he is reading included capital expenditure on public utilities, transport and communications - things like the railways, the Harbour Board, the power station and so on. These are not included in the Government's Development Estimates. The grand total includes various items. Let us take the first two lines of Table 2.11, for instance. "Transport and Communications" includes the Telephone Board. We are spending millions of dollars on such items. "Public utilities" will include the Power Station at Pasir Panjang. This is not development expenditure of the Central Government with which we are concerned in the Development Estimates before us. You are not comparing similar things.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: My colleague has pointed out to me, Sir, that if you turn to the next page, at Table 2.12, the amount spent under the Singapore Harbour Board and the Singapore Telephone Board is only a comparatively small sum. Anyway, the point is that

Column: 1544

the expenditure by the P.A.P. Government has fallen far short of what it should have been.

    Mr David Marshall: Hear, hear!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Again, of the $67.8 million, which I mentioned a little while ago, $34 million is to be spent on housing.
